bibl.title: Despatch from W. H. Randall to John L. Cadwalader
Despatches from U.S. Consuls in Sierra Leone, British Africa, 1858-1906

div1.p: Consulate of the United States of America at Sierra Leone

I have the honor to inform you that on my arrival in Sierra Leone 26 ultó. I made application to His Excellency Governor Kortwright for permission to act temporarily in my Official Capacity This permission was granted on the 2nd inst.
The Form of Consular Bond I have signed & sent to Messrs Mansfield & Roberts of Boston that they may procure the necessary securities and forward to the State Department.
The Oath of Allegiance I cannot consistently take having been born in Manchester County of Lancashire England and therefore a British subject.

I have the honor to be
Sir,
Your Obedient Servant
W H. Randall
div1.fw:
John L Cadwalader Esqr
Assistant Secretary

div1.p: The oath must, in my opinion, be taken. The Act of July 2, 1862 (12 Stats. 502) prescribes the "iron clad" oath to be taken by every person elected or appointed to any office of honor or profit in the civil, military or naval service. That oath has been and is now required from Consuls who are not in the class of persons named in the Act of July 11, 1868 (15 Stats 85) whose legal disabilities have been removed. These oaths are prescribed by the Revised Statutes sections 1756 and 1757.
The oath must be taken before the appointee can enter upon the duties of his office or be entitled to any part of the salary or other envolvements.
